section.title: The Control Protocol
section.t:
In Section 12.2.6 of , the control protocol is introduced. There is no specification of a control protocol, and indeed there need not be such a protocol in use for any given implementation, but a set of requirements are provided to describe the interaction between the MDS and the DS, For the purposes of this draft, there are three broad requirements of such interactions:
NFSv4.1 clients MUST be able to access a file directly through the MDS and not the DS. I.e., the MDS must be able to rerivie the data from the consituent DSes and present it back to the client via normal NFSv4.1 operations. Whether the MDS allows access over other protocols is strictly an implementation detail.
The MDS MUST be able to restrict access to a file on the DSes when it revokes a layout.
The DS MUST honor the byte range restrictions present in the layout. I.e., if the layout only provides access to the first 2 MB of the file, then any access after that MUST NOT be granted.

There are some notable absences from those broad requirements:
The enforcement of authentication and authorization so that restrictions that would be enforced by the metadata server are also enforced by the storage device. Examples include both export access checks and if the layout has an iomode of LAYOUTIOMODE4_READ, then if the client attempts to write, the I/O may be rejected.
While DSes should make such checks on the layout iomode, does not mandate that all Layout Types have to make such checks.
The allocation and deallocation of storage. I.e., creating and deleting files.
This lack of MUST on LAYOUTIOMODE4_READ sounds bogus. Why wouldn't all Layout Types do that?
